Glossary

  • Accountability
    The duty of organisations to show they follow GDPR rules and can prove it (e.g., through staff training, security systems, policies).

  • Automated Decision-Making
    Decisions made solely by algorithms or software, without human input. Under GDPR, individuals can request human review of such decisions.

  • Biometric Data
    Unique biological characteristics used for identification (fingerprints, facial recognition, iris scans).

  • CCTV (Closed-Circuit Television)
    Surveillance cameras recording activity in public or private spaces. Under GDPR, the recordings count as personal data.

  • Consent
    Permission given by a person for their data to be used. Under GDPR, it must be clear, informed, and freely given.

  • Cookies
    Small files stored on your device by websites to remember your preferences or track your activity online.

  • Data Breach
    When personal data is lost, stolen, leaked, or accessed without authorisation.

  • Data Minimisation
    Collecting only the personal information that is truly necessary for a specific purpose.

  • Data Processing
    Any action performed on personal data – collecting, storing, using, sharing, or deleting it.

  • Data Protection Authority (DPA)
    The national regulator in each EU country that enforces GDPR rules and investigates complaints.

  • Data Protection Officer (DPO)
    A person within an organisation responsible for overseeing data protection policies and GDPR compliance.
  • Data Retention / Storage Limitation
    Personal data cannot be stored forever – it must be deleted when it’s no longer needed.
  • Digital Footprint
    The trail of information you leave online.
    • Active digital footprint: information you share deliberately (posts, comments, emails).
    • Passive digital footprint: information collected in the background without you actively giving it (cookies, browsing history, metadata).

  • Digital Identity
    The collection of data points (e.g., name, email, browsing history, location, online activity) that form your “virtual fingerprint” online.

  • Encryption
    The process of converting data into code to protect it from unauthorised access.

  • GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation)
    EU law that governs how personal data is collected, stored, and used, giving people more control over their own information.

  • Integrity and Confidentiality
    A GDPR principle requiring organisations to keep data safe from leaks, hacks, or misuse.

  • Lawful Basis for Processing
    The legal reasons an organisation can collect or use personal data (e.g., legal obligation, contract, consent, public interest).

  • Metadata
    Hidden information attached to digital files (like the time, location, or device used to take a photo).

  • Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
    An extra layer of security requiring more than one proof of identity (e.g., password + SMS code or fingerprint).

  • Personal Data
    Any information that can identify a person, directly or indirectly (e.g., name, email, phone number, IP address, location, photos, social media activity).
  • Profiling
    Automatic processing of personal data to evaluate things about you (e.g., predicting spending habits, job suitability, or creditworthiness).

  • Purpose Limitation
    Personal data can only be used for the reason it was originally collected, not for unrelated purposes.

  • Right to Access
    Your right to ask an organisation what data they have about you.

  • Right to Be Informed
    Your right to be told clearly what data is collected, why, and how it is used.

  • Right to Data Portability
    Your right to transfer your personal data from one service provider to another in a readable format.

  • Right to Erasure (Right to be Forgotten)
    Your right to ask for your data to be deleted when it is no longer needed or collected without proper consent.

  • Right to Object
    Your right to refuse certain uses of your data (e.g., for marketing purposes).

  • Right to Rectification
    Your right to correct incorrect or outdated personal data.

  • Right to Restrict Processing
    Your right to stop an organisation from using your data temporarily while keeping it stored.

  • Special Category Data
    Sensitive data that needs extra protection, such as health information, religion, ethnicity, biometric data (fingerprints, facial scans), or sexual orientation.

  • Third-Party Service
    An external company or provider that processes personal data on behalf of another organisation (e.g., cloud storage provider).
